snippet.title: What do Buddhists believe happens after death?
snippet.description:
"Simply the mind continues, because as we've discussed in previous times, the mind is a stream of awareness which is not generated from physical causes. And so although the, as it were, the hotel of the body collapses at the moment of death, collapses as a suitable kind of receptacle for the stream of consciousness, the stream of consciousness travels on."

Lama Jampa Thaye is an extraordinary Buddhist master. He met his first spiritual teacher, Karma Thinley Rinpoche, at the age of 20 in 1973 and his other principal masters include H.H. Sakya Trizin and H.H. Karmapa (both the 16th and the 17th). As a result students of Lama Jampa Thaye are in the rare position to be able to receive teachings from both the Sakya and Karma Kagyu traditions of Tibetan Buddhism, which Lama Jampa delivers with exceptional clarity, down to earth humour, and compassion. For information of where and when Lama Jampa is next teaching see www.lamajampa.org

snippet.title: Ajivika, Buddhism and Jainism: Why the 3rd Shramana religion "Ajivika" was lost after 2000 years
snippet.description:
When Buddhism and Jainism were taking roots in India, they were just two of more than 62 religious groups that originated in India during the sixth century BC. Of these 62 religions only Buddhism and Jainism survived to the modern ages and the rest perished with time leaving hardly any trace behind. But one of those schools managed to survive for the next two thousand years, only to vanish forever during the late medieval times.  This was the third-largest religious group having its origins in the Shramana tradition and was followed by a large population for the next several centuries. This was the Ajivika sect. But this religion was lost in India after remaining the third largest Shramana religion in India for more than 2000 years. 
The founder of this religion Makhhali Gosala was one of the most radical and colourful religious figures and he was preaching at the same time when Buddha and Mahavira were roaming around the Gangetic plains of India. 

#Ajivika #Religion #Goshala

snippet.description:

snippet.title: We Worry About Problems We Don't Even Have | Eastern Philosophy
snippet.description:
In reality, problems cannot exist without a perceiver, as circumstances aren‚Äôt troublesome without someone or something identifying them as such. So, if there‚Äôs nothing inherently problematic about reality, doesn‚Äôt that mean that we humans repeatedly (and on a grand scale) worry about problems that don‚Äôt even exist?
